Award.AwardTitle: NanoEHS: A Workshop Focused on Fundamental Science Needs, November 1, 2014, Boston, MA

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1441457
This proposal is to conduct a workshop to examine fundamental science needs in NanoEHS. Research in this topic has reached a plateau of understanding by using fundamental testing methods. New approaches to deeper scientific questions are needed. The workshop will identify new questions in order to bring a better understanding of the interactions of nanomaterials with living systems.

The goals of the workshop are as follows:
1. Engage a broad range of participants to focus on the theme of the workshop topic NanoEHS: Fundamental Science Needs
2. Identify areas where fundamental studies are needed to better understand NanoEHS.
3. Identify challenges and opportunities in understanding NanoEHS: Fundamental Science Needs, i.e. identify problems, techniques and methods including, but not limited to, the role of computation and theory, size-dependent behavior for very small particles such as quantum size effects, and surface structure.
4. Articulate the importance of fundamental physics and chemistry within interdisciplinary approaches to NanoEHS: Fundamental Science Needs and identify opportunities for collaboration.
5. Prepare a manuscript to a journal that summarizes and highlights the workshop discussion and findings.
6. Disseminate workshop findings further in a symposium at an upcoming Sustainable Nanotechnology Organization (SNO) Meeting or some other appropriate meeting venue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF award "NanoEHS: A Workshop Focused on Fundamental Science Needs, November 1, 2014, Boston, MA" focused on organizing a workshop with attendees from all over the country.  The workshop brought together a diverse group of investigators working in the highly interdisciplinary area of Environmental Health and Safety of Nanotechnology (NanoEHS). Most of the attendees were from academic and government laboratories.  The topic of the workshop, NanoEHS: Fundamental Science Needs, focused on identifying and highlighting fundamental science needs in NanoEHS research. Nanotechnology involves the development of materials with dimensions below 100 nanometers. Therefore, it is important that research focused on environmental, health and safety considerations of nanotechnology be addressed by the scientific community. The workshop was held in Boston in November 2014 on the Saturday before the SNO (Sustainable Nanotechnology Organization) meeting. 

Following the workshop, a workshop report was written with input from all attendees. This report was then submitted for publication  in the journal Environmental Science:Nano where it was peer reviewed and then published.   A number of recommendations were given within the article and a conceptual framework for this important topic was outlined. The peer-reviewed publication insures widespread dissemination of the workshop discussion and recommendations.  Additionally, the workshop recommendation has been presented and discussed at scientific meetings.
